comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: See the comments here www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7332270140/ Here are a few pics of HMAS Australia and HMAS Canberra which appeared in the SMH a few weeks later. I gather they both had refits (minor and major) over the years, so it's worth seeing how they both appeared at this time...hopefully the SMH had the captions right...I can't tell them apart just going on these pics! HMAS Australia - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16747736 HMAS Canberra - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16747740 Here are some other pics from the newspapers...though the further they are away from December 1930, they are perhaps less helpful: HMAS Australia - at Sydney, May 1930 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16685889 ; at Burnie, March 1931 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article67709125 ; at Sydney August 1931 (rear view) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16828660 ; at Freemantle, September 1931 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article75765165 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article38523136 ; at Sydney, November 1931 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16826339 ; HMAS Canberra - in dock at Cockatoo Island, January 1930 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16614912 ; at Sydney, June 1930 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16696941 ; at Devonport, March 1931 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article67709139 Just for interest, here's another fantastic Sam Hood pic...of Captain Will Chalmers, then of HMAS Australia, chatting to Rosemary Shepherd (who I've discovered later became a famous naval wife!)...it was taken at a naval cricket match played at Rose Bay in January 1931...the SLNSW has quite a few other pics taken on this same occasion www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/5443760127/

comment._content: [love it!]

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
The ship in the foreground here is HMAS Australia since the wheelhouse has square windows, not HMAS Canberra as captioned.

HMAS Canberra's wheelhouse had round windows.

In the first two Sydney Morning Herald articles referenced by Quasymody above, you will note that the photograph of HMAS Australia depicts the characteristic square wheelhouse windows, as they are in this photograph.

I'm viewing this on a tablet device at the moment so I cannot add a note to the photograph outlining the wheelhouse windows. I.ll try tomorrow when I use a desktop computer.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Brilliant, thanks everyone! Based on the evidence of the Harbour Bridge construction, plus BobMeade's evidence regarding the wheelhouse windows, we have changed our data to HMAS Australia as this seems the most likely. Thank again for your help.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 41311545@N05
comment._content: Many thanks ANMM for this wonderful series of images, whose release adds so much to the visualisation our social history, as does your whole Sam Hood Studio Collection. Taken in the Depression era, this and its companion images - your Object NOs. 00034838 [crane ride] and Object No. 0034839 [slippery slide] - are just a joy to behold. Now, CORRECTIONS AND A MEA CUPLA : forget the round and square wheelhouse windows distinction between HMAS CANBERRA [I] and HMAS AUSTRALIA [II] for a moment - it did not apply until modifications to CANBERRA some time after 1933, and I think you should go back to your original caption. This image is almost certainly HMAS CANBERRA [I] holding her series of children's parties at Garden Island on the weekend of December 12-13 1931, as described in the Sydney Morning Herald articles to which you had links from beachcomberaustralia under Pic Object NO. 00034838, the crane ride image. Note it is the same crane ride, and the same unusual flag flying above the slippery slide kids entertainment as shown in Pic, Object No. 00034839. So, the round and square wheelhouses question. I feel I may be responsible for Bob Meade's perception on this, and I had myself accepted it as a blanket distinction, given to me also by an expert commentator. I've applied it as an identifying distinction many times, but I now find it did not apply until after some bridge work modernisations on CANBERRA l sometime after 1933. Hence, we'll have to make a number of corrections in our own collections. Reviewed salient points supporting this: *In their original configurations, both HMAS CANBERRA [I] and HMAS AUSTRALIA [II] arrived in Australia in 1928 and 1929 with the same original and old-fashioned County Class 'ocean liner' look, and both with large square, pretty ugly box-type wheelhouses above the bridge, both with square windows. Evidence: Ross Gillett's 'Australian an d N ew Zealand Warships 1914-1945, p87. * CANBERRA still had this square wheelhouse with square windows when she was photographed by the celebrated NZ photographer Sydney Charles Smith at Wellington's Kings Wharf in September 1933, as shown here: www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/3908140912/. *Some time between Sept 1933 and 1937 CANBERRA's bridge was modified and modernized, resulting in rounded wings above the wheelhouse at the Director Tower level, and round portholes or scuttles in the wheelhouse structure, in place of the square windows there previously. From this point on she is distinguishable from HMAS AUSTRALIA [II]. Source for this 1937 dating, pics shown in John Bastock's authoritative but limited edition book 'Australia's Ships of War' [Angus and Robertson, Sydney 1975] page 106, particularly the Allan C. Green image in the middle of that page. . Hence, from 1937, CANBERRA [I] looked like this, with round scuttles in her wheelhouse... www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/5491719366/ Sorry again for any confusion caused. Warships are continually modified, and tracking those changes in photographs can be a continual process. Glad if anyone can more precisely date CANBERRA's bridge modifications in the 1930s - standard book references and online sources don't seem to have it. Concluding: I now feel certain this photo shows CANBERRA doing the publicized childrens christmas parties in mid-December 1931, same as the companion images, and as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald. Oh, in the background here are a Modified Town Class Cruiser, probably HMAS BRISBANE [I], in reserve and being stripped, and a Flower Class survey/sloop ex-mineswseeper, probably HMAS GERANIUM, also in reserve, the smaller vessel alongside the cruiser.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's HMAS Canberra in Cockatoo Island dock January 1934 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17040876 ; at Adelaide March 1934 (different bridge) ; at sea April 1934 (?different bridge) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article92351292 ; at Fremantle in September 1934 (?different bridge) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32954429 ; at Fremantle again in October 1935 (different bridge) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article85732191; All up I'm voting for HMAS Australia, 6th or 7th December 1930, per the SMH reports of the 1930 children's parties nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16736735 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16736812 . If the 3 children's party pics were all taken on the same occasion, then the state of construction on the Harbour Bridge which we see here www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7332270140/ suggests December 1930...I now think it's probably fair to assume the SMH reporter got the ships right...I can't explain why Sam Hood's caption appears to be incorrect on both year and ship...maybe he didn't add the caption until quite some time later...

comment.author: 65534701@N08
comment._content: I think it is most likely HMAS Canberra as the ship features a Rear Admiral's flag at the mast head and 'Canberra' was the flag ship.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65534701@N08] Good find! But if we're looking at December 1930 (and I'd say we are), then HMAS Australia was the flagship...per this SMH item HMAS Canberra became the flagship in early 1931 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16769743 ; this Hobart Mercury item gives the date of changeover as 29 May, 1931 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29907266

comment.author: 41311545@N05
comment._content: Good research quasymody. Like Kim [sailorsam4]  I too am still holding to CANBERRA  Dec. 1931,  simply because we know Sam Hood was there taking photographs then, and that same odd flag appears here  - but, on belatedly reading the SMH report  you have presented on the similar Christmas parties that took place on HMAS AUSTRALIA  in Dec. 1930, it's very possible, even likely he was there then too, so both conclusions are possible and just about equally supported by evidence. I think it has been a terrific exercise, producing so much information, and it has excited a lot of interest and comment on these benign Navy-community events.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05] The Admiral's flag is a great clue...completely missed by all the landlubbers (my excuse is I spent most...but not all...of my childhood living 600-700kms plus away from the sea!)...the state of construction on the Harbour Bridge is of course the other main clue...I'd argue that the caption on Sam Hood's pic is a red herring rather than a clue...but I'd concede it's certainly a puzzling red herring...if Beachcomber hadn't noticed the state of construction on the Harbour Bridge here www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7332270140/ we'd all probably have settled with HMAS Canberra, December 1931 and moved on...I'm blaming him for this! I'm still voting HMAS Australia, December 1930.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05] What a lovely comment to leave Kookaburra2011, thank you! It seems we cannot lay this debate to rest! Such a riddle. Did you read that [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/]? It's all your fault! :P What are your thoughts on this? We think it's a bit of a puzzle, still not completely convinced by either. Although, as you say quasymody, the bridge construction below is a pretty strong indication regarding the year:
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Ha! I have been watching this discussion with much interest and a certain amount of guilt about starting something I can not complete. I don't think the discussion is over yet, and if anyone can come up with definitive differences between AUSTRALIA II and CANBERRA I at various times, there may be a whole lot of photos all over the interweb which will need to be re-titled. Every time I think I have found a difference between the two ships it doesn't work out with other photos, particularly the excellent collection in [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05]'s photostream. I wondered why the ships had two anchors on the starboard bow and only one on the port (a red herring). I wondered why some pictures of both ships had a large Federation 7-point star under the bridge - did this denote the flagship at the time? All very confusing. I think it must have been particularly difficult for the proverbial Drunken Sailor c.1930 finding the right ship after a big night out in the Cross!

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Well if I am wrong, and it looks as though I am, I cannot blame my good friend Kookaburra2011.  I too had accepted the wheelhouse window differences as "a blanket distinction", but Kookaburra2011 has presented me above with some detailed and cogent information to the contrary. Likewise, information of which I was previously unaware.

I no longer argue that this is HMAS Australia (II). I'm unsure which of the two possibles this is.

comment._content: !!! comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65534701@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Hmmm, perhaps after all this discussion and in light of the great research posted above by all of you, we cannot safely assume that all these photographs were taken at the same event. My instincts tell me that the pic with the children hoisted in the crane was taken on board Australia II in December 1930. Also that this pic was taken at the same event. Based on two factors: the bridge construction being the big one, and the appearance of who I believe to be Rosemary Game, see this article for a comparison of her quite distinctive features. Having said that, you could argue that this is a less convincing piece of evidence, as identifying people is often such an unreliable way of dating/labelling photographs. This particular photograph, on the other hand, should be labelled HMAS Australia or Canberra 1930(?) - 1938...because we cannot be certain it was the same event or that it was one vessel or the other. Although, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/] certainly does offer some interesting arguments, suggesting that this particular image, as separate from the others, possibly depicts Canberra in 1931. It gets pretty confusing! By the way, welcome to the discussion sailorsam4!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Just going on what we see...I'd say that the pic of the children in the crane basket was taken in December 1930...assuming that Sam Hood didn't do a bit of post production and photoshop the December 1930 Harbour Bridge into the pic. Beyond this, I'm not at all certain of anything...I'm speculating and assuming...I'd be surprised if the pic of the children on the slippery slide wasn't taken on the same occasion...mainly because the children we see in the crane basket appear to be the same crowd...but of course this is the pic which carries the inscription 'HMAS Canberra, December 1931' (though the issue re who wrote the inscription and when might be something worth exploring)...the third pic might well have been taken on a different occasion...though the fact that we see the elephant flag in pics 2 & 3 is interesting...I haven't yet abandoned hope that we might be able to track down a newspaper item in a yet to be digitised newspaper which might enable us to be more definite...there's also the possibility that other photos might yet turn up in the various collections which will be helpful...though sometimes other pics might also open up new cans of worms...eg www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/7653426404/ ...all up this puzzle is quite fascinating...but I've put it in my too hard basket for the time being! Just for interest, here's a great pic of HMAS Australia in the Sutherland Dock in January 1929... news.google.com/newspapers?id=_rRVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LJYDA...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] We had considered that prospect, otherwise how can we explain the anachronism? There is quite a bit of evidence suggesting that this is the party on Canberra in 1931, including the inscription on the other negative (object 00034839). But then, there's the incomplete bridge, staring us in the face. There is, as you say, the other possibility they were taken on different occasions, and perhaps the lady in white is a red herring? This seems less likely though. Thanks for the links. We might put together two sets, one on HMAS Australia and one on Canberra, so people can compare...and the debate can rage on :P
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 65534701@N08
comment._content: The main clue in this photo is the flag at the masthead. If it is a Rear Admirals flag it would indicate Rear Admiral Evans, flag officer for the Australian Squadron 1929-1931, on 'Australia'. If in fact it is a Commodore's pennant it would indicate Commodore Leonard Holbrook, flag officer the Australian squadron May 1931-April 1932, on 'Canberra'.  BTW the four funnel ship in the background is most likely HMAS Adelaide as it had a different shaped bridge. It isn't HMAS Brisbane which had a platform between the Control at the top and the Bridge, which was unique.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65534701@N08] Thank you for that information sailorsam4 we have put that into our database record. This is the kind of detail we love to read and add to our records. Welcome to our photostream by the way!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 65534701@N08
comment._content: Thank you ANMM. I commented earlier saying the ship was 'Canberra,' mistakenly thinking it was flag ship at that time. I have [after much detailed study] detected a unique, tell-tale structural clue which tells me this ship is HMAS Australia, and with the Rear Admiral's flag (Evans) at the masthead it would most likely be circa 1930. The ship at the rear would have to be 'Geranium'. The bridge was modified to give it the double story appearance late in its life, there is a similar photo of it in the Brisbane river, but not evident in earlier photos. 'Geranium' was to be scrapped a year or so after this picture was taken.

comment.author: 66546790@N07
comment._content: The cruiser in the background is exactly the Adelaide.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
